snippet: Now that Munch’s famous image has set a price record, it may be a while before we look at it and see only the familiar existential dread.
abstract: Editorial on Edvard Munch's 1895 pastel The Scream bringing nearly $120 million, the highest auction price ever paid for a work of art; suggests that now that the piece has moved to the top of art's 10-most-wanted list, it will be a while before one can look at the work and see only the old, familiar existential dread. (M)
lead_paragraph: Looking at Edvard Munch's 1895 pastel ''The Scream,'' it's hard not to see it as a commentary on the price it brought at Sotheby's in New York this week -- $119,922,500, the highest auction price ever paid for a work of art. In a pose treasured by winners of beauty pageants (as well as trick-or-treaters and many others), Munch's figure on a bridge seems to be shrieking with -- you decide. Elation at such a fantastic figure? Horror at anyone -- it was sold to an unidentified telephone bidder -- spending so much money on a single object? Now that ''The Scream'' has moved to the top of art's 10-most-wanted list, it will be a while before we can look at the work and see only the old, familiar existential dread.
